6/ This is precisely why companies report key metrics on a per share basis - this allows all shareholders and prospective holders to normalize aggregate metrics (revenue, expenses, etc)

5/ But the aggregate value of a system is *not* set from the top-down. It's set by buyers and sellers in an open order book from the bottom-up.

The system will only be as value-able as *marginal buyers and sellers value it*

4/ As a system designer, it's natural to think about the system from the top down, and from this, it flows that a system with ideal governance (doesn't matter what ideal is for the purposes of this argument) should be value-able in aggregate

3/ Now for governance

You can make the reasonable argument that governance is valuable (note that Bitcoin maximalists will disagree with this assertion) because governance allows a complex system to work in the long run to manage scarcity among a diverse, heterogenous population

2/ This math works because you can value the annuity at the aggregate level, *and you can securitize it such that someone can own some fraction of the asset, and the fractional owner can also value the asset on a pro-rate basis

1/ If your discount rate is 5%, you can value an annuity of $100 as $100 / 5% = $2000

Now, you can take that $2000, and divy it up into say 1000 shares, each of which is worth $2

Each $2 share is therefore entitled to receive $.10 / year.

0/ The problem with valuing governance is a classic bottoms-up  / top-down asymmetry with regards to how to value it
